utterances: I know I was still definitely scared at this point.
Like a week after.
And it's sort of this way of addressing it openly because we're at an age where it's like you can't deny that this happened or sort of like regress.
You accept that this happened and you try and understand it.
But I think we're also just trying to make ourselves that we were so aware of the situation that that in itself would kind of keep us safe.
It wasn't until later that I realized all the things we were afraid of in 2001 have actually happened.
We did go to war and even though we might forget sometimes, there were more terrorist attacks.
They just didn't happen here, but in Indonesia, Spain, England and India.
I guess we expected there would be more catastrophic life-changing events right in our backyard.
Looking back, it doesn't seem like our lives changed as much as we thought, or at least as much as we feared.
It seems like little changes have defined us more.
Three years ago my mother and I moved to Chicago, and in all that time living in the Midwest no one has ever mentioned September 11th to me.
When my friends and I talked, we were all more worried about SAT scores than another terrorist attack.
As much as September 11th has been in our minds these last five years, we all agreed that it felt really good to get together and talk about it.
Unidentified Man #1: So in five years, are we doing this again?
Unidentified Man #2: Absolutely.
Unidentified Man #1: All right.
I'll be here.
We're going to be seniors in college in five years.
Imagine that.
We're going to be seniors in college.
Emily Dickinson Mason is a senior this year at Francis W.
Parker School in Chicago.
We heard from her classmates who are still at Washington D.C.'s Oray School: Max Brumby, Caroline Goodman, Lizzie Borges, Clay Solomon, Natalie Groger and Hope Palmer.
Far from the Middle East, Islamic dress has become the subject of intense debate in the Netherlands.
There is a proposal to ban the burqa, which covers the entire body, except for the eyes.
Supporters of the ban say the burqa oppresses women.
Opponents call the ban unnecessary and racist.
NPR's Rachel Martin reports.
Behind the Dutch Parliament in The Hague is one of the Netherlands diverse Muslim neighborhoods home to immigrants from Turkey, Morocco, Afghanistan, and Surinam.

At a corner bakery, customers line up for sweet pistachio pastries, and piping hot donor kabobs; one of the customers, Sasari Oktonentaski (ph), is a Kurdish Turk who's lived in the Netherlands for two decades.
He says the proposal to ban the burqa will improve live for Muslim women.
(Speaking a foreign language)
Most of the folks that I talked to in the Michigan militia were very much distancing themselves.
They were saying that - we don't have an agenda of overthrowing the government.
We're simply concerned about our own protection, living off the land, survivalism, gun practice, those sorts of things.
Which is why the Hutaree group, the heavily armed Christian militia arrested last month just outside of Adrian, Michigan, worried other militia members so much.
Yeah, I'm Jim Gulliksen from Adrian, Michigan, nice little small town that used to be off the map - and now is very much in the spotlight.
Gulliksen hands me his card.
It reads Lenawee Volunteer Michigan Militia: The Original Homeland Security.
A former Navy corpsman now in charge of the paint and hardware section of a nearby Wal-Mart, he's the militia group's CEO.
I'm one of those people that was very anti-militia and all this.
I thought they were a bad thing until my wife talked me into actually sitting and listening to my son explain what it was all about.
And I learned a lot.
As Gulliksen sees it, the militias in Michigan aren't out to destroy the government.
They are out to maintain it.
They can lend a hand to authorities.
He said the group has a good relationship with the local sheriff.
I honestly feel that if there was an emergency like a natural disaster or a missing person, I don't think they'd have a problem calling on us to help.
You know, if it was more of a law enforcement-type thing, rioting or something like that, he may be a little hesitant.
Now, this isn't to suggest that Gulliksen and the people who regularly show up to train with his militia are happy with the way things are in this country.
They aren't.
But we're not - violence is a very last resort.
It's more, we want people to wake up, realize what's happening, how many of their liberties they are losing and...
This is where in the past, the apocalyptic talk might have crept in.
...and get out to the ballot box and vote people in that are going to support the liberties and bring them back.
Local militias are trying hard to change their image.
Lenawee's militia has adopted part of a highway.
They're trying to work with Habitat for Humanity, have collected coats for needy kids.
That's a far cry from how the Hutaree militia, the group arrested last month, allegedly operated.
In this nation, we think we are free, but you need a certificate to be born, a license to drive or permit to build, a number to get a job, and even a paper after you die.
That's a portion of an FBI recording of Hutaree leader David Stone, obtained by NPR.
This was taped secretly while Stone and other members of his group were driving to Kentucky for a militia rally.
Stone was practicing a speech he planned to give there.

People in this nation, as well as some around this world, are waiting for those individuals, like you see sitting in this room - they're supposed to be down there - to actually make the decision to go to war against this evil, greedy new world order.
Some of the Hutaree members used to train in the woods with other regional militias, militias like Mike Lackomar's group.
Stand by...
Back in the woods, Lackomar walks over to his gear and begins to pack it up.
He says the Hutarees were a little odd, training for ambushes, concealment, fire team movements - all the skills that might be needed in a firefight.
They trained at Level 10 all the time.
They focused more on the military aspect than on the civil aspect, which we try to balance out.
Dina Temple Raston, NPR News.
This report was part of an NPR investigation which also examined the Hutaree militia, whose members are accused of plotting to kill police.
You can find that report, and see some of the militia members' bullet-riddled trailers, at npr.org.
It's WEEKENDS on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Guy Raz.
(SOUNDBITE OF MOVIE, ""THE HOUSE I LIVE IN"")
Drugs is a monster.
The killing, the stealing, those people being destroyed, it's devastating.
Since 1970, the war on drugs has cost over two and a half trillion dollars and resulted in more than 44 million arrests.
During that time, sales of illegal drugs have grown steadily.
That statistic hangs on the screen like a warning sign in a new documentary by Eugene Jarecki.
It's called ""The House I Live In."" Jarecki is the man behind the award-winning film ""Why We Fight."" It's about the military industrial complex.
Now, he's tackling the war on drugs and its consequences.
The movie debuts at the Sundance Film Festival this weekend, and it begins with a very personal story.
It's a story of how drugs upended the family of the woman we just heard from, Eugene Jarecki's childhood housekeeper, Nanny Jenner.
Well, Nanny Jenner is like a second mother to me.
I've known Nanny, and she's known me, my whole life.
Her name is actually Nanny.
It's her birth name.
She lost one of her sons, of course, to AIDS.
He was a drug user and contracted it from a dirty needle.
Yeah, yeah.
And I grew up with her children.
I knew them very closely.
And Nanny is African-American.
And I think we all grew up in a kind of a utopian post-civil rights mindset where we thought America had entered a really new time and that opportunity awaited us.
And what I watched happen over the years was that members of her family who've grown up alongside me, they didn't find the same kind of opportunities I found.
They weren't blessed in the ways that I found myself to be blessed by circumstance.
Instead, they met a new kind of challenge, what Michelle Alexander, who's in the film, calls a new Jim Crow.
(SOUNDBITE OF MOVIE, ""THE HOUSE I LIVE IN"")
Well, in any war, you've got to have an enemy.

And when you think about the impact, particularly on poor people of color, you know, there are more African-Americans under correctional control today, in prisoner jail, on probation or parole than were enslaved in 1850, a decade before the Civil War began.
And that's something we haven't been willing to look in the mirror and ask ourselves.
What's really going on?
But what I discovered is that something was holding a great mass of black people back in a new and very different way, and that's what the film starts to uncover.
(Speaking foreign language)
The reopening of the area means Abeer Abdullah can now safely take her two children to a nearby park and garden to play.
It's an outing the family wouldn't have dared to make even a few short weeks ago.
(Through translator) Before we couldn't even open our front doors or visit our relatives and neighbors.
Now it's much better.
God willing, it will stay this way.
The 24-year-old housewife nibbles on sunflower seeds and pushes her son on a park swing, offering thanks to Allah - not the Iraqi government - for the improved security.
(Through translator) The people, I tell you, the people did this.
They got tired and challenged all the problems - the insurgents.
Not the government.
The government did nothing.
Our neighborhoods are still very bad, but here we can stay out now, until nine or nine thirty at night.
